channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Guards Beat and Tortured Kherson Prisoners, Leading to Deaths
item.description: Ukraine has charged four members of Russia’s National Guard with war crimes in Kherson. The four acted with such impunity, the authorities say, they did not mask their identities.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Petro Zhadan, a former soldier, was held for 73 days and heavily beaten at a detention center in Kherson, Ukraine. “All my body was blue,” he said.

item.title: Kyiv Residents Scramble for Shelter From Daytime Russia Missile Barrage
item.description: A barrage on Tuesday came after an attack on Monday sent schoolchildren screaming and running for shelter as explosions echoed across the Ukrainian capital, a rare daytime aerial assault on the city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients and medical staff members taking shelter in the basement of a hospital in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Ugandan President Signs Anti-Gay Law That Includes Death Penalty
item.description: The legislation is among the most restrictive of its kind in the world and was condemned by Western leaders and the United Nations human rights body.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Abubaker Lubowa/Reuters
item.media:description: The Ugandan Parliament in May during the passage of an anti-gay bill. Lawmakers passed an earlier version in March.

item.title: She Said Her Professor Sexually Harassed Her. His Wife Won Damages.
item.description: A case involving a graduate student and her art history professor illustrates the tangled state of sexual power dynamics in Japan.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meiko Sano, who brought a sexual harassment lawsuit against her art history professor, in Tokyo.

item.title: Alberta’s Vote Will Test American-Style Far-Right Politics
item.description: An election in Alberta will be a test of a premier who has said that she models her politics after those of prominent right-wing U.S. politicians.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Danielle Smith, the leader of the United Conservative Party, while campaigning this month in Calgary.

item.title: Sudan War Strikes a Blow to the Country’s Emerging Art Scene
item.description: Dozens of Sudanese artists and curators have fled their studios and galleries in the capital, jeopardizing thousands of artworks and imperiling an art scene central to the 2019 revolution.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dahlia Abdelilah Baasher, a Sudanese artist, painting at her new home in Cairo. Dozens of artists and gallery owners have fled Sudan and don’t know the fate of their artworks.

item.title: Erdogan’s Victory in Turkey’s Presidential Election: Key Takeaways
item.description: Crises including earthquakes and inflation did not stop the re-election of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The vote was seen as free but not fair, as he used his power to tilt the playing field.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan celebrating in Istanbul on Sunday. He has retained fervent backing from a significant part of the population.

item.title: Guyanese Teenager Is Charged With 19 Counts of Murder in School Dorm Fire
item.description: Investigators have accused the 15-year-old student of starting the blaze in anger after her mobile phone was confiscated.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Mahdia Secondary School in Mahdia, Guyana, was gutted by a fire that officials said had been deliberately set.

item.title: Spanish Prime Minister Calls Snap Election for July
item.description: Pedro Sánchez, who leads a fragile coalition government, made the announcement after his liberal party lost ground to conservatives in regional and local elections over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain, shown at the White House on May 12, said he would dissolve Parliament and hold elections on July 23.

item.title: A Climactic Opening
item.description: Floods, landslides and fires are making it harder to get national parks ready for summer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Bets on Wind Power, Which Missiles Can’t Damage as Easily
item.description: Bombarding the power grid has been an essential part of Russia’s invasion, but officials say it would take many more missile strikes to badly damage a wind farm than a power plant.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: New wind turbines at the Tyligulska wind farm in May in the Mykolaiv region of Ukraine.

item.title: Will Erdogan’s Victory Soften Turkey’s Opposition to Sweden in NATO?
item.description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, re-elected as Turkey’s president, is expected to toughen up at home but seek better ties with Washington and ratify Swedish membership of the military alliance.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan celebrating his victory in Istanbul on Sunday.

item.title: The Mystery of the Disappearing van Gogh
item.description: After a painting by the Dutch artist sold at auction, a movie producer claimed to be the owner. It later vanished from sight, with a trail leading to Caribbean tax havens and a jailed Chinese billionaire.
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times. Fine Art Images/Heritage Images, via Getty Images; Imagno, via Getty Images.

item.title: China Announces Plan to Land Astronauts on Moon by 2030
item.description: The announcement formalized a timeline that Chinese scientists have set out before, as the United States and China ramp up competition in space.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A billboard displaying Chinese astronauts at a �satellite launch facility in northwestern China. On Monday, China said it plans to land a person on the moon by 2030.

item.title: One Indian State Is Desperate for More Babies
item.description: India will soon be history’s most populous country. But the growth is uneven, and the Himalayan state of Sikkim is offering cash incentives to encourage births.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Smita Sharma for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman undergoing an ultrasound at the Newlife Fertility Center in April in Siliguri, India. Although India is set to become the most populous nation on earth, the populations of some regions are shrinking.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Erdogan’s victory in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Chris Mcgrath/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan speaking to supporters at the presidential palace after winning reelection.

item.title: Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey Is Re-elected
item.description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan has given few indications that he intends to change course at home, where he faces a looming economic crisis, or in foreign policy, where he has vexed Western allies.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan celebrating his victory in Istanbul on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A U.S. debt-limit deal
item.description: Also, a reader-made playlist.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden arrives on the South Lawn of the White House after returning to Washington, D.C., on Sunday.

item.title: At Least 3 Die in Clashes on Iranian-Afghan Border
item.description: The fighting comes amid rising political tension between the two countries over the flow of water from the Helmand River in Afghanistan into eastern Iran.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Helmand River snaking through the province near Nadali, Afghanistan.

item.title: Modi Opens India’s New Parliament Building as Opposition Stays Away
item.description: The complex is a testament to the prime minister’s power to get things done, but the ceremony also put the nation’s political divisions on display.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India carrying a scepter during an inauguration for a new Parliament building on Sunday in New Delhi.

item.title: What’s in the Debt Deal
item.description: Leaders from both parties have reached an agreement.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy said a deal had been reached to raise the debt limit for two years.

item.title: Meet the New Mayor: How a Refugee Won Over a Conservative German Town
item.description: The election of Ryyan Alshebl, a young man who fled Syria, offers surprising lessons for a Germany wrestling with its multicultural identity after an influx of refugees in 2015.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ryyan Alshebl, center, at the May Day festival in Ostelsheim, Germany. A Syrian refugee who arrived in 2015, he is the town’s new mayor.

item.title: Richard Revesz and His Agency Are Remaking the Pollution Fight
item.description: Richard Revesz is changing the way the government calculates the cost and benefits of regulation, with far-reaching implications for climate change.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.category: Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (US)
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Revesz in Washington, D.C.

item.title: A Wagner Fighter’s Escape to Norway Creates a Problem for His Host
item.description: Andrei Medvedev fought with Russia’s Wagner mercenaries in Ukraine, then requested asylum in Norway. The authorities there must now weigh his plea against solidarity with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Andrea Gjestvang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrei Medvedev, who fought with Russia’s Wagner mercenary group, is seeking asylum in Norway, while providing information on Wagner’s fight in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Repels Large Russian Drone Attack on Kyiv
item.description: More than 40 drones were intercepted over Kyiv, where city officials said at least one person had been killed, probably by falling debris.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage inside a building struck by debris in Kyiv on Sunday.

item.title: Emilia-Romagna, Italy, May Face More Violent and Frequent Storms
item.description: Experts have linked recent deadly rains in the north of the country to climate change, but decades of urbanization and neglect helped lay the groundwork for a calamity.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Elisabetta Zavoli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrea Ricci, 26, sat exhausted last Saturday on a dinghy that he used to help deliver goods and water to people in the flooded district of Lugo, Italy.

item.title: Some Canadian Indigenous See Hudson’s Bay Building as Hollow Gift
item.description: The company chartered centuries ago to found the colony that became part of Canada last year gave a building to the Indigenous that is heavy in symbolism. The move is being criticized by some as hollow.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:description: The Hudson’s Bay Company’s former flagship store, built in 1926, has long been an iconic fixture of downtown Winnipeg.

item.title: Summer’s Unofficial Start
item.description: It’s Memorial Day Weekend, the start of summer, ready or not.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Official in India Drains Part of Reservoir to Retrieve Phone
item.description: Rajesh Vishwas, a food inspector, used a diesel pump to empty part of a reservoir where he had lost his smartphone.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Amrit Mandavi/Shutterstock
item.media:description: A view of the district in Chhattisgarh State, India, where the Paralkot reservoir is.

item.title: As Covid Infections Rise, China Rejects a Return to Lockdowns
item.description: The authorities say that cases are up, and one doctor estimates that there could soon be 65 million cases a week. But China appears determined to move on.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press
item.media:description: A tourist shopping street in Beijing last month.

item.title: Canada Needs to Hurry on A.I. Oversight, Experts Warn
item.description: The measures of an artificial intelligence bill won’t go into effect until 2025. For some, that’s too late.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Geoffrey Hinton, a leading expert in artificial intelligence, photographed in 2017 at the University of Toronto.

item.title: Putin’s Ukraine Strategy: Ignore War in Public and Outlast Foes
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia looks like a commander in absentia, treating the war in Ukraine as unfortunate but distant. His options have narrowed, but he is still betting on outlasting his foes.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed Russian military vehicles sitting at a makeshift open-air museum this month in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: For These Veterans of U.S. Military, ‘Free’ Health Care Is a 5-Hour Flight Away
item.description: Citizens of three Pacific Island nations, eligible to serve in the U.S. military, find it hard to make use of the health benefits they have earned.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Akasha Rabut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ovenny Jermeto, a veteran from the Marshall Islands, in the waiting room at the Spark M. Matsunaga Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Honolulu.

item.title: German Plan Would Ease Path to Citizenship, but Not Without a Fight
item.description: Months of wrangling over a new law have Germans asking a fundamental question: Are we a country of immigrants?
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Peter Tschentscher of Hamburg, Germany, presenting a certificate at a citizenship ceremony in February at City Hall.

item.title: Ukraine’s Top Commander Signals Counteroffensive Could Be Imminent
item.description: A blunt statement, accompanied by a slickly produced video of Ukrainian troops preparing for battle, appeared designed to rally the nation and to spread anxiety among Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier from the 79th Brigade firing toward Russian positions near the town of Marinka in eastern Ukraine last week.

item.title: Russian Missile Strike Hits Ukrainian Hospital
item.description: A Russian missile killed at least two people and wounded dozens more at a hospital, while apparent Ukrainian strikes hit occupied cities in the south.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: A Russian missile strike destroyed part of a hospital complex in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Berlin Police Investigate Roger Waters Over Nazi-Style Uniform
item.description: Mr. Waters, a founder of Pink Floyd, who has long been critical of Israel, has worn similar clothing in the past when playing songs from Pink Floyd’s album “The Wall.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roger Waters performing in 2012 at Yankee Stadium in New York. He wore a similar outfit at concerts in Berlin last week, for which the German authorities are investigating him.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich Appeals Russia’s Extension of His Detention
item.description: Already jailed for two months on charges for which Russia has provided no evidence, Mr. Gershkovich has been ordered to remain in prison for three more.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, 31, appearing in court in April after being arrested in late March and accused of espionage.

item.title: Belgium Sentences Students Over Hazing Death of Sanda Dia
item.description: Sanda Dia, a 20-year-old Black student at the Catholic University of Leuven, died in 2018 after members of an elite fraternity forced him to drink fish oil, swallow goldfish and stand in an ice-filled trench.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Koba Ryckewaert
item.media:credit: Sebastien Van Malleghem for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph of Sanda Dia in his brother’s home in Oostakker, Belgium.

item.title: For Ukraine Military, Far-Right Russian Volunteers Make for Worrisome Allies
item.description: Some fighters who led an incursion into Russian territory this week have neo-Nazi ties. “I worry that something like this could backfire on Ukraine because these are not ambiguous people.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denis Kapustin, in black, the leader of an anti-Putin group of ethnic Russians, has been identified as a neo-Nazi by the Anti-Defamation League.

item.title: Russian Public Appears to Be Souring on War Casualties, Analysis Shows
item.description: Support for the war in Ukraine remains high but could potentially turn if concern over the high numbers of casualties persists, according to FilterLabs AI.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned Russian tank in a forest north of Kharkiv, Ukraine, in January. Russia’s battlefield casualties could threaten support for President Vladimir V. Putin if concern about them turns the public against the war.

item.title: Iran Frees Belgian Aid Worker in Prisoner Swap
item.description: The aid worker, Olivier Vandecasteele, had been sentenced to 40 years in prison for spying. The former diplomat was convicted of plotting a 2018 bomb attack.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Belgian Government, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Belgian government, Olivier Vandecasteele stands in a Belgian military plane transporting him back to his country, on Friday.

item.title: The Counteroffensive Is Coming
item.description: We preview what is next in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: The 80th Air Assault Brigade of the Ukrainian Armed Forces fired a barrage of 122mm Grad rockets in the direction of Bakhmut during a night operation in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Passenger Arrested on Suspicion of Forcing Open Plane Door Mid-Flight
item.description: A man was arrested on suspicion of unlocking an emergency exit on an Asiana Airlines flight in South Korea when it was about 700 feet off the ground.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Yonhap/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An Asiana Airlines plane sitting on the tarmac after an emergency landing at Daegu International Airport in South Korea on Friday.

item.title: How Turkey’s Erdogan Rose to Power
item.description: Turkey’s leader faced a criminal conviction, mass protests and a coup. Instead of hurting or ending his political career, they helped him accumulate ever more control.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Umit Bektas/Reuters
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey greeting supporters in Ankara, Turkey, this month.

item.title: Colombia’s Peace-Whisperer Makes Plenty of Enemies
item.description: Leyner Palacios’s push for dialogue, forgiveness and reconciliation has made him the face of peace in Colombia — and subjected him to death threats.
item.dc:creator: Silvana Paternostro
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leyner Palacios served on the Truth Commission, which spent four years examining Colombia’s internecine conflict, fought between 1958 and 2016.

item.title: Ukraine NATO Bid Mirrors West Germany’s During Cold War
item.description: West Germany joined NATO in 1955, choosing security over immediate territorial integrity. Some suggest the same path could be the best guarantee for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Anton Brink Hansen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, delivering a video message at a Council of Europe summit in Reykjavik in May.

item.title: Vietnam Activist Jailed for Mocking Official’s Salt Bae Meal
item.description: A powerful Communist official ate a gold-encrusted steak in London. An activist who poked fun at the excess was sentenced to more than five years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Chau Doan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Burhan Sönmez on the Tensions Between Politics and Art in Turkey
item.description: Burhan Sönmez, who is president of PEN International, discusses the tension between politics and art and the role of literature in authoritarian societies.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Hatice Sahin
item.media:description: Burhan Sönmezm, a writer who is part of Turkey’s ethnic Kurdish minority, sees the upheavals of the Erdogan years as only the latest chapter in an ongoing struggle of Turkish power and Turkish art.

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Woos Voters in Re-Election Campaign
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has rock star appeal at his election rallies, promising to lead Turkey to claim its rightful place as a global power if he is re-elected in a runoff on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey campaigning in the capital Ankara in April.

item.title: Gasoline Prices, a Source of Pain Last Year, Have Come Way Down
item.description: Reasons include a stronger supply of oil and weaker-than-expected demand, energy experts say. Some people are saving hundreds of dollars on fuel.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Shawn Thew/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A gas station in Alexandria, Va., this week. Because gas prices are posted on big colorful signs, they can have a powerful psychological impact on consumers.

item.title: Restaurant Chain Franchises Face Scrutiny From the FTC
item.description: Troubles at the restaurant chain Burgerim highlight concerns about whether franchisees need more protection in their contracts with franchisers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Franchises are ubiquitous in the American business landscape but concern is rising about the poor disclosure of business risks.

item.title: ‘Different Standards’: The Struggle of Indigenous Journalists in Australia
item.description: The departure of the TV host Stan Grant has set off a conversation about race and racism in the country’s media industry.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Jason McCawley/Getty Images
item.media:description: Stan Grant announced that he would step back from his television hosting duties after receiving “relentless” racial abuse.

item.title: Russia’s Wagner Mercenaries Say They'll Pull Out of Bakhmut
item.description: After seizing the city in eastern Ukraine after a long, brutal fight, the Wagner mercenary force is turning it over to the depleted Russian Army to defend.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Concord Press Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: An image released by Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s press service that it says shows him with Wagner fighters in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Thursday.
